title: Runner should be able to register itself with the Computer
body:
Currently, the resolving strategy of the test runner is very static. The only way for a Runner to participate is via the @RunWith annotation. This is more than fine as long as the runner does only support top-level classes.

Now with the HierarchicalContextRunner (see https://github.com/bechte/junit-hierarchicalcontextrunner), which has more and more stargazers, it's somehow different. This runner supports member classes and uses them to form a context hierarchy, i.e. member classes will inherit all initializations from the outer classes, without having to extend them. This is a great benefit.

Now, when the tests are executed, everything is fine. But when someone restarts a test of a lower hierarchy, then the test tools does not recognize the @RunWith annotation of the top-level class. Instead it tries to run the very most inner-class with the default JUnit4 runner, leading to a "The inner class XYZ is not static."-Exception.

I wish we could have an extension point other that the @RunWith annotation, that allows us to contribute to the way, JUnit resolves the runner, namely, the Computer mechanism should be more extendible.

If that's not possible, maybe we can change the current Computer in such a way, that given a non-static member class, the Computer resolves the top level class and verifies if this class is annotated with @RunWith and uses this runner instead of the default JUnit4 runner, which anyways does not support this kind of classes, at all.

For the latter approach, we would only have to change the current implementation of the AnnotatedBuilder.runnerForClass(Class) method to perform the check within a for-loop (see attached pull request).

What do you think about this change?

title: Support for hierarchical context hierarchies
body:
This is a pull-request for issue #816.

#816: Support for hierarchical context hierarchies - RunWith annotation will be resolved along the hierarchy of non-static member classes.

Discussions on this topic should happen in #816. I provided this pull-request mostly to show the changes more graphically.

title: External version of AssumptionViolatedException
body:
This is a pull-request for issue #390.

Just subclassing and deprecating the internal version and updating references. I'm wondering if there's a better package for the external version?

- Remove the unmaintained list of completed items; new work

- Remove completed or obsolete items from to-do.txt.

title: Optimize memory consumption in junit.framework.Assert
Remove Eclipse files and directories, modify .gitignore
body:
The following files and directory were stored in repository: .settings, .classpath, .project
They are unnecessary now, after migration from Ant to Maven. All IDEs like IntelliJ IDEA, Eclipse, Maven have got special plugins to work with Maven projects.

Also I put additional entries in .gitignore file to prevent this files in future.

title: Add Serializable interface for comparators
body:
It is not something important, just Java SDK recommendation: http://docs.oracle.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/util/Comparator.html

> Note: It is generally a good idea for comparators to also implement java.io.Serializable, as they may be used as ordering methods in serializable data structures (like TreeSet, TreeMap). In order for the data structure to serialize successfully, the comparator (if provided) must implement Serializable.

title: Throw TestFailedOnTimeoutException instead of plain Exception on timeout. Fixes #771
body: Created a separate branch with the changes I've made and fully merged from upstream/master. This one should probably merge better than the newline-broken tree in PR #777

title: Replace StringBuffer to StringBuilder
body:
StringBuffer is synchronized, StringBuilder is not.
Replacing StringBuffer to StringBuilder could make a **tiny** performance optimization.

Additional information:
StringBuffer: http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/lang/StringBuffer.html
StringBuilder: http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/lang/StringBuilder.html

title: JUnitMatchers either() Javadoc incorrect
body:
The example Javadoc for the either() method is a copy of the example for the both() method. 

See here: http://junit.sourceforge.net/javadoc_40/org/junit/matchers/JUnitMatchers.html#either(org.hamcrest.Matcher)

It should be something like:
```
assertThat(string, either(containsString("a")).or(containsString("b")));
```

title: Replace usage of StringBuffer to StringBuilder
body: Squash commits for #824

title: Highlight Java code in 4.11 release notes
Fix possible NPE in method equals (ParameterizedAssertionError)
Java syntax highlighting in markdown-formatted release notes.
Add Javadoc for org.junit.experimental.theories.Theory
body: I understand that this functionality in package "org.junit.experimental" and it is very simple for understanding, but it will be great to have minimal documentation in this class for beginners.

title: Close possibility to make reassignment for some constant-fields
body:
I found some "public static" fields that should be final (in my opinion), because someone could change them and break the internal behavior.

List of fields:
* MethodSorter.DEFAULT
* MethodSorter.NAME_ASCENDING
* Filter.ALL

title: JavaDoc docs not working
body: Not really sure if this is where I should report this, but the JavaDoc docs available at http://search.maven.org/remotecontent?filepath=junit/junit/4.11/junit-4.11-javadoc.jar don't really work. There's something wrong with the styling or something like that.

title: Added profile "code-coverage" to run cobertura-maven-plugin
body:
It could be useful to check code coverage and cobertura-maven-plugin will do it.

I've added new profile "code-coverage". You need to activate it and run "mvn clean package" to build report about code coverage. Report about code coverage is available in "target/site/cobertura".

![image](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/578021/2237965/3c093b62-9bd3-11e3-9917-f796a8eced26.png)

title: Renaming variables for codebase consistency
body:
I've been working on a research machine learning-based tool (link: http://groups.inf.ed.ac.uk/naturalize/ ) tool that analyzes source code identifiers and makes suggestions for renaming them. The goal is to reduce unnecessary diversity in variable naming and improve code readability. This pull request is only a small sample of the suggestions made for JUnit.

No functional changes were made in any of the commits.

title: Modification to the ParameterizedTest to support private field for the @Parameter annotation.
body: This is a change to both support public and private field for Parameterized test. For some developer, it is "more logical" to use private field for all fields.

title: Feature: assertThrows(...) to check for expected exceptions
Provide an API to get a count of assertion methods called
body:
I would like to suggest a new JUnit api for junit 5 to address the following;

Here is a UML Diagram
https://github.com/adligo/junit/blob/master/diagrams/JUnit5RunApiSuggestion.jpg

1) I would like to correlate code coverage, assertion counts and other test data into a better api for statistics, so that users of junit can have a better ROI of their testing effort.
2) I would like to write test summaries for Ant that were compatible with @BeforeClass , @AfterClass and Ant's legacy xml and plain test report formats for use with Jenkins.


I have been able to do some by modifying the JUnit 4 api adding my data
this code is currently here;
https://github.com/adligo/junit/blob/master

Also Kevin, I think the modifications that would be required to the Description class are significant enough to call a api change.

title: test_stats
body: just forking again and redoing my changes on the adligo_test_stats branch.

title: Junit 4/5 api to count asserts and allow ant to write test report the way it used to using JUnit 3
Adligo test stats
body:
The diagrams are not intended to be merged, but just for conversation for junit 5.

I would like the source code to go into the JUnit 4.12 or 4.13 so I don't have to maintain a long term fork,
so I can get assert counts out of regular junit, and test method names out of the test Results so I can make ant test report compatible with the junit 4 api.

Cheers,
Scott

title: JUnit 4/5 api suggestions
body:
Ok I think I have posted this 3 or 4 times, and they seem to disappear so I am posting again.

I would like to purpose the following run api for junit 5, so please be super critical exc, but keep the issue open so others can comment;
Here is a uml diagram
https://github.com/adligo/junit/blob/adligo_test_stats/diagrams/JUnit5RunApiSuggestion.jpg

In a nutshell I would like to correlate the TestCases with what is getting tested using the results of test runs including;
AssertCount (ie how many times have things like assertEquals been called)
CodeCoverage (something like EclEmma, but included as part of JUnit, so that the code coverage can be matched up to the tests in a more sane way)
Ant legacy reports (I need which testMethods were run and their times)
New Stats
   percentage of instructions covered
   percentage of lines covered
   percentage of assertions to instructions
   average instructions per line (this should be smallish (ie 1.1) for well refactored code)

title: BlockJUnit4ClassRunner#withRules is private
body:
Hi,

all other with* methods are protected in BlockJUnit4ClassRunner so I can override them in my own runner.

I do not understand why withRules is private. withRules is executed in BlockJUnit4ClassRunner#methodBlock so I have to override all methodBlock and I need to implement withRules in my target runner which is basically done as copy-paste (which is pretty error prone and does not work for some reason).

Am I getting something wrong or why is that method private and not protected as any other in that with* family?

title: java.awt.HeadlessException:  No X11 DISPLAY variable was set during Bamboo build in a class which extends java.applet.Applet
Remove redundant "extends" clause
body: Clean up code and make it more readable by eliminating redundant information.
